snippet: American politicians don't take much prodding to feel a special love for Israel. And listening to voters in Iowa, the love just got stronger.
abstract: American politicians don't take much prodding to feel a special love for Israel. And listening to voters in Iowa, the love just got stronger.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES, Iowa - On Tuesday, at 6:55 p.m. sharp, I come to the school gym that serves as Precinct 025 to meet Adam ("Just call me Adam" Adam), torchbearer of the Rick Perry for President campaign. "Where are you from?" he asks. "Israel," I say. "You mean the nation of Israel?" "Both the nation and the land but mostly the State of Israel." His candidate, Texas Governor Perry, keeps talking about how important it is to defend Israel, to stand with Israel. Adam will make his contribution to this important cause by defending the visiting Israeli journalist from whatever menace caucus night might hold.
